This matter does not come under the Commission"s responsibilities.

Question No 69 by Jonas Sjöstedt (H−0370/99)

Subject: Protection of persons providing information

Before the Commission resigned, Paul van Buitenen, the internal auditor, was suspended from duty on half pay. Since then, he has obtained a new post in another Commission department. This and similar cases raise the question of the need to allow Commission staff the freedom to provide information, which in Sweden, for example, is a right enshrined in the constitution.

Does the Commission consider that the right of Commission staff to provide information should now be a matter for debate in the light of events prior to the Commission's resignation?

Answer

The Commission has noted the honourable Member"s comments regarding the freedom of expression of the Commission"s staff and the staff of the other institutions. Possible solutions to this must be considered in the light of their own merits and the practices in all the Member States of the Union.

Question No 70 by Philippe Monfils (H−0371/99)

Subject: The UIP case

The cartel of three major Hollywood film studios (UIP) which have pooled their distribution services for Europe is covered by a derogation under Article 85(3) of the Treaty of Rome. This derogation is due to expire, and the Commission is currently considering whether or not to renew it. Given the significance of the UIP case – which cannot be treated as run‐of‐the‐mill – and the enormous political pressure which is being brought to bear on the Commission in this connection, should the outgoing Commission not postpone taking a decision on this matter, so as to allow the new Commission to take a decision which is of vital importance for the future of the European film industry?

Answer

Since UIP in 1993 applied for a renewal of the 1989 exemption, the Commission has thoroughly investigated whether UIP has been involved in any anti‐competitive behaviour or activities not envisaged at the time of the previous exemption. The Commission has also examined UIP's effects on the film distribution market.

The Commission has notably found that, although the market has shown a sound tendency of growth and expansion, UIP's Community wide market share has decreased from 22 % in 1989 to 13 % in 1997.

Furthermore, UIP is willing to give a number of new undertakings to accommodate concerns raised against UIP (e.g. UIP will not coordinate the release dates of the parties' films or use block bookings).

The Commission is likely to publish a notice in the Official Journal soon inviting third parties to comment on a possible renewal of the exemption.

In competition cases, where the Commission acts as the guardian of the Treaties, the outgoing Commission continues to assume its responsibilities and considers that there is no reason to postpone procedures.

Question No 71 by José Valverde López (H−0374/99)

Subject: EU model for medical prescriptions

The free movement of persons, freedom of establishment for health professionals and the single market in medicines mean that a single model for medical prescriptions must be established. This must include a diagnosis or diagnostic indications. If effective information is to be provided to the patient and medication is to be monitored, an individual ‘health card' is also necessary.

Does the Commission consider it necessary to undertake technical studies and consult the interested parties with a view to introducing legislation in the forthcoming months to lay down a model for medical prescriptions and ‘health card'?

Answer

The Commission is following closely key developments in Member States' health systems, including the impact of internal market legislation on the health sector in Member States.

The scope for legislation, however, is limited by the public health provisions of the Treaty, which leave Member States responsible for the financing and organisation of their health systems.

As regards medical prescriptions, the Commission does not at present consider that introducing a uniform model is necessary in order to guarantee the functioning of the internal market.

Concerning the introduction of health cards, the Commission refers the honourable Member to the follow‐up it has given to the Parliament's resolution of 17.04.1996 on the Leopardi report (OJ C 141 of 13.05.1996, p. 104). It still considers that major legal, political and technical obstacles remain before the development of Community legislation in this field could be considered.

The Commission, in close cooperation with Member States' Ministries of Health, continues to keep both matters under consideration.

Question No 72 by Konstantinos Hatzidakis (H−0380/99)

Subject: Utilisation by the Greek government of Community funds to highlight Government achievements prior to the elections

The Greek Government has recently been using Community resources to fund a series of advertising campaigns to draw attention to the Greek Community Support Framework; however they fail sufficiently to highlight the Community nature of the projects concerned and overemphasise the Government's contribution. There are also reports of similar campaigns to be launched shortly. These campaigns coincide with a large‐scale election campaign by the Government party which also makes extensive reference to Agenda 2000: this makes Greek citizens even more confused. All these measures are being taken a mere two months before the Euro‐elections in June 1999 when the country is in a pre‐electoral period, and the impression is easily created that Community resources are being used to fund the Government's election campaign. Given that in similar circumstances in the local elections in 1998 the Commission, following my question (H−0543/98)(4) , intervened with the Greek Government and reached an agreement with the latter that the information campaign should be postponed until after the two‐month pre‐electoral period, will it say whether it intends to take similar action in this case, since the problem is on a larger scale this time because European elections are involved?

Question No 77 by Georgios Anastassopoulos (H−0390/99)

Subject: Use of Community funding for government publicity in the run‐up to elections

Why does the Commission not carry out the necessary checks to ensure that the funds provided from the various Community programmes (Community Support Framework, European Social Fund etc.) are actually used to promote the Community's contribution to the development of the Greek economy and not for government publicity?

In view of the fact that this tendency has recently become more pronounced in the run‐up to the European elections on 13 June, will the Commission say what measures it has taken and whether it considers it appropriate that these government campaigns with Community money be stopped and information to the Greek public about Community programmes be resumed after 15 June, as happened last year before the regional and local elections in Greece?

Joint answer

The Commission has already set out its position on this issue at Parliament"s part‐session of June 1998(5) . In general, it is satisfied with the implementation of the publicity and information campaigns that are cofinanced by the ‘technical assistance" operational programme of the Community support framework for Greece.

A group made up of representatives of the relevant ministry and the Commission, under the authority of the programme"s monitoring committee, supervises the campaign and decides on the measures that are to be taken in case of any specific problems. It was in this context that it was decided last year to temporarily suspend the campaign during the local elections.

The same reasoning applies to the campaign before the European elections. As a result, the Greek authorities announced that the campaign would be suspended from 1 May to mid‐June.

Question No 73 by María Sornosa Martínez (H−0382/99)

Subject: Measures to reform large psychiatric hospitals and promotion of out‐patient facilities in Greece

In 1984, the EU began to subsidise – and is continuing to do so – the improvement of mental health services in Greece, initially through Regulation 815/84/EEC(6) and subsequently through the Psychargo programme. The results so far have been poor. The fundamental reasons why there has been no reform of the mental health system to date are that the experience, planning and efficiency of the mental health services in the other Member States have not been taken on board, that the funds given to the big psychiatric hospitals have not significantly changed their outmoded practices and that the Greek Ministry of Health and Welfare has not taken a global approach to planning, using a timetable and, principally, Greek government resources to set up and operate services in the community (outpatient facilities).

Will the Commission change the entire modus operandi of the system by implementing the Psychargo programme and what practical measures are planned to improve the effectiveness of reforms in the large psychiatric hospitals and to promote outpatient facilities?

Question No 74 by Honório Novo (H−0383/99)

Subject: Effectiveness of Psychargo programme funding in Greece

The state of Greek psychiatric units (asylums) and the inadequate standard of psychiatric prevention and care generally, together with the failure of Regulation 815/84/EEC(7) and the ineffective use of resources allocated under this Regulation, have occasionally exercised the European Parliament, the relevant Commission services and the international media.

The Greek governments between 1984 and 1995 and also the Commission have been held responsible for failing to implement the five‐year psychiatric reform plan drawn up in 1984: resources were misallocated and the programme was a failure so that the shortcomings persist to this day.

Will the Commission say whether the relevant Commission services have taken measures to ensure that the new funding for the Psychargo programme is allocated effectively?

Question No 75 by Pedro Marset Campos (H−0384/99)

Subject: Improving the functioning of psychiatric asylums and the network of outpatient facilities

The European Parliament has already considered the tragic state of psychiatric care in Greece. One of the most serious problems which Regulation 815/84/EEC(8) failed to address successfully was the lack of basic outpatient facilities, mental health centres, mobile units, day centres, child‐guidance centres, etc.

Today only a small portion of the population is covered by these services. However, experience in the EU Member States shows that an improvement in the functioning of asylums and de‐institutionalisation are impossible unless such a network of outpatient facilities exists. Will the Commission say whether it intends, in cooperation with the Greek government, to use the new subsidies that have been approved under the Psychargo programme for this purpose?

Joint answer

Under Regulation 815/84 an important reform was introduced into the Greek psychiatric care system involving the gradual replacement of the institution‐based system of psychiatric care by a network of alternative prevention led and therapeutic mental health services and facilities based in the community or in general hospitals. Moreover, provision was made for the development of social and vocational rehabilitation services throughout the country.

Regulation 815/84 applied from 1984 to 1995. After 1995, psychiatric reform remained fragile because it had not been accompanied by the required legal and administrative arrangements for its consolidation and further development.

In order to secure a more systematic continuation of the reform in the context of the 1994‐99 Community Support Framework for Greece, and in particular under the Operational Programme on Combating Exclusion from the Labour Market, the Commission requested the Greek authorities to prepare an action plan for the completion and consolidation of psychiatric reform. In the framework of this plan, which has been called ‘PSYCHARGOS', actions eligible under Structural Fund Regulations could be financed by the Community.

In parallel, a Bill on Mental Health was drafted. It is expected to be adopted soon by the Greek Parliament. The Psychargos plan, which is largely dependent on the Bill, will then be finalised.

In the meantime, the Commission has approved a special action (which will be part of the PSYCHARGOS plan when this will be finalised) to be financed by the Operational Programme on Combating Exclusion from the Labour Market. This action includes therapeutic and training interventions for the rehabilitation of people with mental health problems residing in all psychiatric hospitals of the country; the creation and development of new extra‐mural structures for independent living and rehabilitation; reinforcing and broadening the training and employment opportunities of people with mental health problems and staffing and training of the staff of the new extra‐mural structures. The relevant activities are expected to be launched by the end of June 1999.

Both during the application of Regulation 815/84 and in the current programming period the Commission has made, and plans to continue to make use of the expertise available in other Member States in the specific field.

Question No 76 by Lone Dybkjær (H−0386/99)

Subject: Blue Flag Campaign – follow‐up to answer to H−0287/99

In question H−0287/99(9) the Commission was asked whether organisations are able to ascertain how many complaints have been received and what they are about in cases where complaints are directed against themselves and are used as a justification for depriving them of financial assistance.

I do not know whether the Commission cannot or does not want to understand the question but the fact is that it has not answered it.

It is understandable that the identity of the complainant should be kept confidential but it is in fact the number and content of complaints that are of interest to those against whom complaints are lodged.

Where the FEEE is deprived of financial aid on the basis of complaints, can the FEEE be granted access to the number and content of such complaints and hence an opportunity to respond to them as long as the identity of the complainant is concealed?

Answer

The Commission decided not to fund the 1999 Blue Flag campaign for both financial and technical reasons. First, the Commission had some questions concerning the administrative management of the subsidy. The FEEE did not provide requested documents justifying expenses on a timely basis.

Second, the Commission was concerned about the allegations of deficient control procedures by the national operators of the campaign during the bathing season, and in particular in case of complaints against FEEE on the handling of its scheme. Given these circumstances, the Commission did not grant financial support for the 1999 Blue Flag campaign under the ‘Call for the submission of proposals for general measures to inform and increase awareness of the environment'.

By letter of 17.2.1999, the FEEE was informed that there were three complaining letters at the moment containing allegations on Blue Flag Scheme (2 concerning Spain and 1 concerning the United Kingdom). As these letters had referred to the Bathing Water Directive(10) , the Commission had registered them as complaints following the Commission rules. However, detailed assessment revealed that the letters did not raise issues of compliance with Community law but other aspects of Blue Flag Scheme, like deficient control procedures by FEEE national operators during the bathing season. As the cases did not raise issues of compliance with Community law, the Commission did not have powers to deal with these complaints and it invited the complainants to address their concerns directly to FEEE. If they did so, FEEE should be aware of the details of the allegations.

The Commission has suggested to FEEE that in the case of complaints from the public, such as those mentioned above (concerning the handling of the scheme), the current response via the national operators should be complemented with some form of independent assessment, in order to ensure that the procedure is fair and impartial.

In the framework of the call for proposals in the field of environment (OJ No C 357, 21.11.1998, 98/357/07), FEEE submitted an application for funding for the year 2000 campaign. This proposal is currently under examination and FEEE, like the other applicants, will be informed of the outcomes of the selection by the end of May 1999.

Question No 78 by Bernie Malone (H−0394/99)

Subject: Restrictions on entry into Kings Inns legal courses

Is the Commission aware of restrictions on entry to professional legal courses in Kings Inns, Dublin, which particularly affect holders of qualifications in other EU Member States, and if so, does the Commission consider that such restrictions are in accordance with EU law?

Answer

The Commission is not aware of any restrictions on entry to professional legal courses at Kings Inn, Dublin, which particularly affect holders of qualifications obtained in other Member States.

It is of course willing to consider any documents and information which the honourable Member may wish to submit in connection with this matter.

Question No 79 by Alex Smith (H−0396/99)

Subject: Public health assessment from plutonium reprocessing

Will the Commission send a team of radiological experts on a special environmental protection mission to Scotland to assess the risks to the environment and the public health of the people of Scotland, the rest of the United Kingdom, Ireland and the Scandinavian countries, including Member States Denmark, Sweden and Finland, arising from the nuclear operations at the reprocessing plants and plutonium stores at Dounreay and Sellafield, the ageing plutonium and tritium production reactor at Chapelcross in south‐west Scotland, the storage of depleted uranium at the same site, and the testing of depleted uranium shells at the Dundrennan test site in Kirkudbright, near Chapelcross; and will it include non‐governmental experts in the visiting mission?

Answer

The Commission has carried out verifications of facilities for monitoring radioactivity in the environment around the reprocessing plants at Dounreay (1993 and 1999) and Sellafield (1993). The other nuclear sites referred to have not yet been included in the programme of verifications due to resource constraints and the prioritisation of visits.

The teams carrying out verifications under Article 35 of the Euratom Treaty do not include experts from non‐governmental organisations. It is the responsibility of the Commission staff comprising the team to ensure the thoroughness of the verifications and the objectivity of the findings.

Question No 80 by Christine Oddy (H−0398/99)

Subject: Recruitment policy and disabled people

What is the European Commission's policy in relation to recruitment of disabled people, including people with hearing difficulties? What equipment and facilities are available to disabled employees? What is the number of disabled people employed by the European Commission and what is the range of disabilities?

Answer

The Commission has adopted a Code of good conduct for the employment of people with disabilities (Ref. E/98/1874 – C(98) 2765, September 22, 1998) demonstrating its political will and commitment to promote equal opportunities for their employment.

The application of this code should ensure reasonable career prospects for those who are selected, buildings and/or working stations are adapted in order to respond to the needs of disabled persons.

Recruitment to Community institutions is done by open competitions. The Commission has tried for many years to avoid any discrimination in this field by giving special support to handicapped candidates for their participation in the different tests of each competition on an equal level with all other candidates.

As far as the number of disabled officials and servants is concerned, such statistics have been till now very difficult to obtain because of the sensitiveness and sometimes confidential character of this kind of data.

Nevertheless, the Code of Good Practice that each Institution will appoint an official or body to be responsible for the implementation of:

. the ‘census' of disabled persons working in the Commission, and
. centralising information in respect of the careers of disabled officials.

Question No 81 by Hans Lindqvist (H−0401/99)

Subject: MED‐TV

MED‐TV is a TV channel broadcasting from London which provides information about Mesopotamia. It can be seen by 40 million viewers and is aimed at Assyrians/Syrians, Kurds, Arabs and Turks throughout Europe.

On 21 March this year, MED‐TV was closed down at the request of Turkey. At the same time, the official Turkish TV channels in Europe are allowed to broadcast heavily tendentious and heroising propaganda.

Official Turkey seems to have acquired jurisdiction and the right to act on European territory. European institutions have not shown integrity in dealing with Turkey's continuing demands to silence any voicing of opinions from minorities in exile.

Millions of people from Christian and Kurdish minorities have been forced to flee from persecution in Turkey. Many of them now live in the EU.

What measures will the Commission take to protect those living in the EU and uphold their right to balanced information and the re‐launching of MED‐TV?

Answer

The honourable Member has raised the issue of the closure of MED‐TV, a satellite channel licensed by the United Kingdom authorities.

Community Law applicable in this area is the Television Without Frontiers Directive (Council Directive 89/552/EEC as amended by Directive 97/36/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council). This directive lays down the legal framework for television broadcasting activities within the Union.

The directive provides that each Member State shall ensure that all television broadcasts transmitted by broadcasters under its jurisdiction comply with the rules of the system of law applicable to broadcasts intended for the public in that Member State. This obligation of ‘home country' control is the basis for granting ‘freedom of reception and retransmission' across the Union.

According to the information available to the Commission, the Independent Television Commission, which is the licensing authority in the United Kingdom, revoked the licence of MED‐TV on 23 April 1999. This was pursuant to its duty to ensure compliance with United Kingdom Law. According to the United Kingdom authorities, the channel was in breach of its licence requirements, and also in breach of UK Law. In particular, the United Kingdom authorities have informed the Commission that MED‐TV broadcast programmes which encouraged acts of violence and which were likely to encourage or incite to crime or lead to disorder; the revocation of the licence followed a period of monitoring by the ITC which had issued a number of warnings to the channel that it was in breach of its licence requirements and the ITC code.

Under these circumstances, the United Kingdom authorities appear to have been executing their obligations under the Television Directive and thus under Community Law.
